title: Why Does Russia insist on still using Armored Trains?
summary: The video explores Russia's historical and current use of armored trains, highlighting their resurgence in Ukraine due to logistical challenges and tradition despite advancements in modern military technology.

title: Absurd Stories from the Afghanistan War
summary: The video recounts two harrowing true stories from the Afghanistan war: the daring medevac rescue of a U.S. Marine impaled with an unexploded RPG and the tragic Kajaki Dam incident, highlighting both extraordinary acts of bravery and devastating operational failures.

title: Bro does Beer Run for his Buddies in Vietnam War
summary: The video recounts the incredible true story of John "Chickie" Donohue, who in 1967 risked his life by sneaking into war-torn Vietnam to deliver beers to his neighborhood friends serving on the frontlines, an adventure later made into book and film.

title: How a Lone US Sub Destroyed Japan's Most Important Ship in WW2
summary: The video details the history and significance of the Japanese aircraft carrier Shokaku, highlighting its major World War II battles, technological advancements, and ultimate sinking during the Battle of the Philippine Sea, marking a pivotal loss for Japan's naval power.

title: Waffen SS vs. Vietcong - Who Would Win?
summary: The video compares the Viet Cong and Waffen SS, concluding that the SS would dominate in open combat due to superior training and aggression, while the Viet Cong’s guerrilla tactics and adaptability would ensure victory in protracted jungle warfare.

title: Japans History Highlights
summary: This video provides an in-depth historical overview of the Yakuza's origins, rituals, organizational structure, and influence in Japan; the evolution and actions of the Japanese military; Edo-period society and culture; and notable events including atomic bomb survivorship and the Yamaichi gang war.

title: Gun Loadouts used by the Worlds most Elite Units
summary: The video explores the specialized weapons and equipment used by elite military units worldwide—including Ukrainian, American, British, Russian, and Israeli Special Forces—highlighting their advanced features and crucial roles in enhancing operational effectiveness.

title: How Tanks are Stolen in War
summary: The video explores the challenges of capturing enemy tanks intact, highlighting historical and modern examples—like Ukraine’s use of abandoned Russian tanks—while emphasizing that forcing crews to abandon vehicles is usually the only practical way to seize and repurpose them.

title: Dirtiest Tricks Used in War
summary: The video explores some of the dirtiest and most underhanded tactics used in warfare throughout history, from sabotaged ammunition in Vietnam to psychological and physical warfare in conflicts ancient and modern, highlighting how pragmatism often overrides honor in battle.

title: Miserable History of Medicine
summary: The video explores the evolution of medical understanding and practices from the 16th century to the modern era, highlighting the deadly health challenges faced by people—such as scurvy, the Black Death, Spanish Flu, and unsafe medical procedures—before the advances of modern science and technology.

title: The Forgotten Stalingrad of Asia (WWII)
summary: The Battle of Kohima (April–June 1944) was a pivotal Allied victory in World War II’s Burma campaign, where British and Indian troops, enduring a brutal siege and fierce combat—epitomized by the “tennis court” fight—repelled the Japanese offensive and turned the tide in Asia.

title: Why you Must NOT Shoot Medics in War
summary: This video explores the historical evolution and challenges of battlefield rules protecting medics and officers, highlighting how conventions like the Geneva Convention sought to shield non-combatants, but were frequently violated—especially during World War II—resulting in deliberate targeting and war crimes.

title: Axis Punishments of WW2
summary: The video details the brutal execution methods and war crimes committed by Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan during World War II, highlighting atrocities such as beheading, use of the guillotine, torture, cannibalism, and live dissection of prisoners.

title: Bizarre and Mysterious: Deaths Throughout History
summary: This video explores history's strangest and most gruesome deaths, from the preserved corpses marking Mount Everest's dangers, to bizarre accidents, notorious assassinations, and unusual medical mishaps, highlighting how fate and circumstance have led to remarkable demises across time.

title: Haiti's Voodoo Dictator from Hell - Papa Doc Duvalier
summary: The video recounts the brutal 1957–1971 dictatorship of François "Papa Doc" Duvalier in Haiti, highlighting his use of violence, voodoo mystique, and the notorious Tonton Macoute militia to terrorize and oppress the Haitian people, resulting in tens of thousands of deaths.

title: Most Fearsome Warriors in History
summary: The video explores some of history’s most feared warrior groups—including Italy’s Arditi, Nepal’s Gurkhas, the Zulu, Comanche, and Māori—detailing their origins, tactics, weaponry, and legendary reputations for bravery and ferocity in battle.

title: Infamous Cases of Cannibalism in History
summary: This video explores historical cases of extreme cruelty and survival, including Aztec human sacrifices, George H.W. Bush's WWII near-capture by cannibals, the cannibalism on Siberia's Nazino Island and in Australian penal colonies, and the infamous crimes of Countess Elizabeth Bathory.

title: Weird Tanks in History - Engineering Fails
summary: This video explores the history of "Frankenstein tanks"—vehicles cobbled together from mismatched or salvaged parts out of necessity or desperation—from World War II through present-day conflicts like Ukraine, detailing notable examples and their effectiveness or failures.

title: STOP Repeating these Military LIES
summary: This video debunks widespread myths about military history—including misconceptions about the French military's reputation, Polish cavalry in WWII, the U.S. military, the vanished battalion at Gallipoli, Roman culture, and the use of wartime fake news and propaganda.

title: Soldier Kamikaze in WW1 (Grenadier's Leap)
summary: The video recounts the heroic defense of Monte Cengio by the Italian Sardinian Grenadiers during the 1916 Austro-Hungarian Strafexpedition, where outnumbered troops fought fiercely—some even leaping off cliffs with their enemies—to prevent an Austrian breakthrough toward Venice.

title: Old WW1 Veterans who Kept Fighting in WW2
summary: This video profiles three elderly World War I veterans—Walter Ernest Brown, Adrien Carton de Wiart, and George S. Patton—who returned to fight in World War II, highlighting their bravery, resilience, and the extraordinary actions they undertook despite their age.

title: 10 Years of YouTube...
summary: Chris Kane of Simple History recounts the channel’s growth from short, founder-run animations to a global team producing longer, in-depth videos, and announces a shift toward Patreon support to fund more ambitious and uncensored historical content.

title: Life inside a WW2 KV-1 Tank (Cross section)
summary: The KV-1 was a heavily armored Soviet heavy tank of World War II, notable for its early combat durability and impact, but ultimately outclassed due to its poor mobility, mechanical unreliability, and the advent of more advanced enemy armor.

title: Dogs of War - The Hero Canines of WW2
summary: This video recounts the heroic deeds of dogs awarded the Dickin Medal—known as the animal Victoria Cross—for their bravery and lifesaving actions in World War II, highlighting their crucial roles in military operations, rescue missions, and boosting human morale.

title: Soldiers Who were Intoxicated in Battle
summary: The video recounts remarkable stories of soldiers in various wars—including the Vietnam, World Wars, and the Philippine-American conflict—whose bravery, endurance, or unconventional actions were often fueled or affected by drugs, alcohol, or sheer willpower, highlighting both their exploits and the complex realities of combat.

title: Stupid Things that Bored Soldiers Do
summary: The video warns soldiers against reckless actions like lighting cigarettes with flamethrowers, cooking with C4, and drinking from gun barrels, explaining how such behaviors endanger lives, create serious health risks, and complicate medics' efforts during warfare.

title: Unique uses for Guns
summary: This video explores the history of unusual and innovative firearms from the 20th century—including the drip rifle, curved-barrel guns, anti-tank rifles, underwater weapons, and periscope rifles—detailing their design, use, and impact on warfare.

title: Napoleon's War On RABBITS
summary: In this video, Napoleon recounts surviving assassination attempts, his infamous rabbit attack, discovering the Rosetta Stone, and his tumultuous relationship with Josephine, reflecting on his legacy and personal life before his exile.

title: Russia's Secret Wonder Weapon
summary: The video explores the history and significance of the tachanka, a horse-drawn machine gun cart used primarily by Russian and Eastern European forces during the early 20th century, highlighting its role in mobile warfare before being replaced by modern vehicles.

title: The CAT Who Refused To Die In WWII
summary: The video tells the legendary story of Unsinkable Sam, a cat who supposedly survived the sinking of three ships during World War II, symbolizing hope and the special bond between sailors and their feline companions, though his true existence is debated.

title: Why Falling Asleep is FATAL in War
summary: The video explains the critical dangers of falling asleep during war—ranging from personal execution and friendly fire to lost battles and entire wars—illustrated with historical examples where sleep deprivation or dozing off led to deadly and disastrous consequences.

title: Real Life GTA Moments in History
summary: This video explores notable criminal events and organizations—including a 1995 San Diego tank rampage, the violent history of Japan’s Yakuza, notorious outlaws like Ned Kelly and Charles Bronson, inventive prison weapons, and the evolution and tactics of elite police and FBI units such as SWAT and the Hostage Rescue Team.

title: Most Unfair Wars in History
summary: This video explores five of the most one-sided wars in history—including the Anglo-Zanzibar War, Persian Gulf War, U.S. invasion of Grenada, Italian invasion of Ethiopia, and the Spanish-American War—highlighting overwhelming disparities in military power and resulting swift victories.

title: The Best Tank of WW2
summary: The video details the development, combat history, strengths, and weaknesses of the Soviet T-34 tank, explaining how its innovative design, mass production, and battlefield performance made it a legendary and decisive weapon in World War II.

title: 1000 Yard Stare
summary: The video explores the origins, symptoms, and evolving misunderstandings of "shell shock" (now known as PTSD) among World War I soldiers, highlighting its devastating impact, mistreatment, stigma as cowardice, and the long-delayed official recognition of sufferers' suffering.

title: UNSTOPPABLE Chinese Soldier who Blocked a Machine Gun with his Body - Korean War
summary: The video recounts the heroic actions of Wang Jicang, a Chinese soldier during the Korean War, who sacrificed himself to block a machine gun and enable his unit's advance at Triangle Hill, making him a celebrated national hero in China.

title: The Rules of war ALL Soldiers MUST OBEY
summary: The video explains the history and principles of international laws and conventions governing warfare, focusing on protections for non-combatants—especially medics—prohibited tactics, and banned weapons, while highlighting violations and the evolution of rules to minimize unnecessary suffering in armed conflict.

title: Stereotypical Ways Countries Fight Wars
summary: The video explores the distinctive war strategies and doctrines of major nations—including the US's emphasis on technological superiority and logistics, Germany's defensive fortifications, China's combined arms and perception of mass infantry, Russia's deep battle and attrition, Vietnam's guerrilla tactics, and France's precision strikes with small, agile forces.

title: Overpowered Guns used to Cheat in Battle
summary: The video explores how various weapons—including shotguns, Uzis, crossbows, air rifles, bayonets, Gatling guns, Tommy guns, and needle guns—were viewed as unfair, dishonorable, or controversial in warfare due to their technological advantages or perceived cruelty.

title: Life Under Evil Communist Regimes
summary: This video explores the horrors and human cost of 20th-century totalitarian regimes, including the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, Stalin’s Soviet Union, Mao’s Great Leap Forward in China, and North Korea’s Kim dynasty, focusing on famine, repression, and mass atrocities.

title: What Makes a Good Gun Design
summary: The video explores the evolution and innovation of gun upgrades, magazine placements, special forces loadouts, and fundamental shooting stances, illustrating how practicality, engineering, and combat experience shape weapon design and effective firearm handling throughout history.

title: Allies and Axis Working Together in WW2
summary: The video explores rare instances during World War II when Allied and Axis soldiers aided or even cooperated with each other, often due to personal convictions or unique circumstances, highlighting events like the Battle for Castle Itter and individuals who switched sides.

title: Imperial Japan's Lost Tiger Tank of WW2
summary: This video explains how Japan attempted to acquire German Tiger tanks during World War II to counter superior American armor in the Pacific, but due to logistical challenges and the Allied invasion of Europe, the tank never reached Japan or saw combat there.

title: The REAL One Man Army (Compilation)
summary: The video recounts the extraordinary wartime exploits and heroism of five soldiers from different eras and nationalities, including Leo Major, Ben L. Salomon, Adrian Carton de Wiart, Christian Craighead, and Hiromichi Shinohara, each of whom performed remarkable feats of bravery and earned distinguished recognition.

title: Maverick 41 - The Story Of Craig Harrison's Sniper Record
summary: The video recounts how British sniper Craig Harrison set a record in Afghanistan in 2009 by achieving the longest confirmed double kill at 2,475 meters, protecting his comrades in combat and later facing serious personal consequences due to his identity being revealed.

title: North Korean Pilot's Daring Defection
summary: The video recounts the dramatic 1953 defection of North Korean fighter pilot No Kum-Sok, who escaped to South Korea with a MiG-15 jet, earning $100,000 and U.S. citizenship while providing valuable intelligence to the Americans.

title: The Worst Betrayals in History
summary: This video recounts five of history’s most infamous wartime betrayals—by the British at Mers-el-Kébir, Canadian leadership in Hong Kong, Benedict Arnold, Vidkun Quisling, and the Fourth Crusade’s sack of Constantinople—highlighting their devastating impact on wars and trust among allies.

title: Useless Overweight Tanks of WW2
summary: The video explores several oversized, experimental tanks from World War II—including Germany's Jagdtiger and GW Tiger P, Hungary's 44M Tas, Britain's TOG II, and the A39 Tortoise—highlighting their massive size, design aims, operational failures, and ultimate obsolescence.

title: Weirdest Attempts to Cross the Berlin Wall (1961-1989)
summary: This video recounts daring and inventive escape attempts from East Germany between 1961 and 1989, illustrating the risks people took for freedom and culminating in the fall of the Berlin Wall, which marked the end of communist rule in Eastern Europe.

title: Do Soldiers Really Shoot to Kill?
summary: The video explores whether soldiers truly "shoot to kill," detailing how psychological reluctance to kill is common, military training aims to overcome this, and while willingness to kill has increased over time, studies remain inconclusive and the true extent is hard to quantify.

title: Why Soldiers Brought These Weird Items To War
summary: The video explores the superstitions and rituals of 20th-century soldiers—including lucky charms, mascot animals, special clothing, and unique pre-battle routines—used to cope with the fears, dangers, and uncertainty of war.

title: Soldier's Mental Health After the War is Over
summary: The video examines Gulf War syndrome—its mysterious symptoms, evolving research, and recent findings linking it mainly to low-level sarin exposure—as well as the historical mistreatment and neglect of psychologically and physically disabled war veterans, particularly after World War I.

title: Hitler's Crazy Plan to Sabotage the United States
summary: Operation Pastorius was a failed 1942 Nazi plot to sabotage American infrastructure that quickly collapsed when two team members betrayed the mission, leading to the arrest and execution or imprisonment of all eight spies before any attacks occurred.

title: Cursed Guns History Should Forget
summary: The video explores several notorious firearms—from the M50 Reising submachine gun to the USFA Zip 22, Apache revolver, and CSRG Chauchat—detailing their design flaws, reliability issues, and reputations as some of the worst guns ever made.

title: Military Deceptions That NO ONE Saw Coming
summary: This video details the history and use of military deception tactics—including decoy equipment and false identities—across the two World Wars, highlighting ingenious strategies like dummy tanks, sniper dummies, and operations such as Mincemeat that misled enemy forces.

title: No, Silencers on Guns are NOT Silent
summary: This video debunks common gun myths perpetuated by movies and video games, including misconceptions about silencers, flamethrowers, shooting ropes, bullet impacts, gun safety when dropped, and the dangers of blank rounds.

title: The True Story of a Forsaken WW1 Tank Crew
summary: The crew of the British WWI tank "Frey Bentos" survived three days trapped between enemy lines during the 1917 Battle of Passchendaele, enduring horrific conditions and heavy fire to prevent their tank from being captured, becoming the war's most decorated tank crew.

title: Guns Disguised as Everyday Objects
summary: The video explores the history and design of disguised firearms—such as briefcase guns, pen and cane guns, glove guns, and covert assassination devices—highlighting their intended use for concealment, espionage, or surprise attacks, and their impact on warfare and spycraft.

title: Why Did So Many N*zis Escape To Argentina?
summary: After World War II, numerous high-ranking Nazis—including Adolf Eichmann, Franz Stangl, and Josef Mengele—escaped justice by fleeing via secret networks, often aided by sympathizers and the Vatican, to Argentina, which welcomed them under President Perón's regime.

title: The Real Story Behind Devotion: Jesse Brown and the Korean War
summary: The video tells the heroic story of Jesse Leroy Brown, the first African-American naval aviator, highlighting his bravery, tragic death during the Korean War, and lasting impact in breaking racial barriers within the U.S. military.

title: The WORST Military Defeats in History
summary: The video recounts several historical battles where smaller or seemingly weaker forces—such as the Vietnamese, Indians at Longewala, Hannibal at Cannae, Nazi scouts in Belgrade, and Māori at Gate Pā—defeated or humiliated much larger, better-equipped militaries through superior tactics, courage, or surprise.

title: Things They DON'T Teach You About The Korean War
summary: This video reveals surprising and overlooked facts about the Korean War, including its status as the first jet-vs-jet conflict, repeated captures of Seoul, severe cold-related casualties, its ongoing unresolved status, international involvement, and its role as the first desegregated US conflict.

title: Acid Gambit - The Most Dangerous Delta Force Mission
summary: Operation Acid Gambit was a daring 1989 Delta Force mission that successfully rescued American Kurt Muse from a Panamanian prison during the US invasion, despite intense combat, a helicopter crash, and numerous near-fatal complications.

title: Why YOU NEVER Volunteer In War First
summary: The video explains why volunteering for certain roles in war—such as mustard gas experiments, night watch, latrine duty, being a "canary girl," or a frontline medic—is especially dangerous and often leads to severe long-term physical and psychological harm.

title: Why The Military Is TERRIFIED Of A 'Broken Arrow'
summary: The video explains the military code "Broken Arrow," highlighting its rare use as a distress signal for imminent danger of being overrun in battle and as a term for nuclear weapon accidents, both indicating situations of extreme crisis.

title: The Soldiers STILL Fighting After WW2 Ended Into The 1950s
summary: This video details the stories of Japanese soldiers who, due to isolation, disbelief, or adherence to Bushido, continued hiding and fighting on remote Pacific islands for years—and even decades—after World War II had officially ended in 1945.

title: The BIGGEST Accidents In War
summary: This video recounts five of the worst accidental disasters in military history—including the USS Thresher sinking, Operation Cobra friendly fire, the failed Desert One hostage rescue, the Sultana steamboat tragedy, and the 1980 Titan II missile explosion—highlighting how complex systems can fail catastrophically from simple mistakes.

title: The Most NOTABLE Assassinations In History
summary: The video explores the assassinations or attempted assassinations of key historical figures—including John F. Kennedy, Theodore Roosevelt, Archduke Franz Ferdinand, Adolf Hitler (Operation Valkyrie), and King William II—analyzing events, motivations, controversies, and their far-reaching impacts on world history.

title: The History Of Nuclear Fallout (Compilation)
summary: This video explores the development and dangers of nuclear weapons from World War II to the Cold War, covering the Cuban Missile Crisis, fallout shelters, nuclear accidents ("Broken Arrow"), and the doctrine of mutually assured destruction, ultimately illustrating humanity’s ongoing vulnerability to nuclear annihilation.

title: Life Inside A Panther Turret Bunker (Cross Section)
summary: During World War II, Germany repurposed surplus Panther tank turrets into heavily armored stationary bunkers—known as "Pantherturm"—to reinforce defensive lines, making efficient use of available resources in response to mounting losses and logistical challenges.

title: History's Biggest Disappointments
summary: This video explores some of history’s greatest letdowns—such as the Titanic, the Gallipoli campaign, the Warsaw Uprising, the Spanish Armada, the Maji Maji Rebellion, and Roman Emperor Didius Julianus—where soaring expectations ended in disastrous reality.

title: Life Inside a Medieval Castle (Cross Section)
summary: The video explains the structure, purpose, and daily life within medieval castles, highlighting their roles as fortified residences for nobility, centers of community and defense, and enduring symbols of power across Europe.

title: Paranoia After The Vietnam War (PTSD)
summary: This video explains how the Vietnam War contributed to widespread, long-lasting PTSD among veterans—marked by debilitating flashbacks and health issues—due to the war’s traumatic experiences, societal stigma, and lack of early mental health support.

title: Life Inside A Sturmtiger Tank (Cross Section)
summary: The video provides a detailed history and technical overview of the German World War II Sturm Tiger assault vehicle, highlighting its design, armament, combat role, limited production, and minimal impact on the war due to its late introduction and small numbers.

title: Police & S.W.A.T. Tactics (Compilation)
summary: This video explores the origins, evolution, training, tactics, and equipment of police special units like SWAT and the FBI Hostage Rescue Team, their roles in law enforcement and counterterrorism, and the historical use of shields and formations in modern riot control.

title: American VS British WWII Bombing Tactics - Which Was Better?

title: The YouTube Prank That Accidentally Killed Kim Jong Un's Brother
summary: This video details how two women, unknowingly recruited for a "prank," assassinated Kim Jong-nam—the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un—with a VX nerve agent at a Malaysian airport in 2017, sparking international intrigue and diplomatic crisis.

title: Most Dangerous Career Paths To Take In The Modern Military
summary: The video highlights some of the most dangerous military jobs—including EOD technicians, forward observers, combat medics, and war correspondents—explaining the extreme risks and high stress they face in combat zones.

title: Everything You Need To Know About D-Day
summary: The video provides an in-depth account of the D-Day landings at Omaha Beach on June 6, 1944, detailing the challenges, heavy casualties, equipment, firsthand experiences—including that of German defender Hinrich Seelow—and the pivotal role of American paratroopers in the Normandy invasion.

title: The REAL History Behind Assassin's Creed Shadows

summary: The video recounts the extraordinary lives of two exceptionally tall soldiers—Woodrow "Woody" Keeble, a heroic Dakota warrior of the Korean War posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor, and Jakob Nacken, Germany’s tallest WWII soldier turned postwar entertainer.

title: The Most TERRIFYING Things To See In War
summary: The video explores some of the most horrifying events in wartime history—including the use of napalm, mass executions, Holocaust death marches, atomic bombings, and cavalry charges—highlighting the enduring psychological and physical trauma inflicted by these atrocities.

title: Samurai VS Knight - The ULTIMATE Battle
summary: The video compares a 16th-century European medieval knight and a Japanese samurai in various combat scenarios, ultimately concluding that the knight wins in most close-quarter battles due to superior armor and weapons, while the samurai prevails with firearms.

title: The OLDEST Soldier On Omaha Beach - D-Day (1944)
summary: Norman “Dutch” Cota, one of the oldest soldiers on Omaha Beach at age 51, played a pivotal role in rallying and leading American forces during D-Day, earning the Distinguished Service Cross and enduring both success and setbacks throughout his World War II military career.

title: Biggest Military Screwups In History
summary: This video explores infamous military disasters and underdog victories throughout history, highlighting how miscommunication, incompetence, or sheer luck have led to catastrophic blunders, unexpected triumphs, and accidental tragedies in warfare.

title: Life Inside The Flattest Tank - STRV 103 (Cross Section)
summary: The Stridsvagn 103, an innovative Swedish turretless main battle tank designed for defensive warfare during the Cold War, featured a low silhouette, fixed gun, and advanced suspension but never saw combat and was ultimately a unique but dead-end development in tank design.

title: The Perfect Medieval Siege Tactic
summary: The video explores the history and evolution of sapping—undermining walls through tunneling—as a siege tactic from ancient times through the medieval era and into modern warfare, highlighting notable examples and advancements across centuries.

title: WW2 Guns Still Being Used Today
summary: This video explores several World War II-era weapons—such as the STG44, M2 Browning, Lee-Enfield rifle, MG42, Madsen LMG, M1911 pistol, M3 Grease Gun, M101 Howitzer, and D44 gun—that remain in use today by various militaries and insurgent groups worldwide.

summary: This video details the development, variants, technical specifications, combat history, and legacy of the Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress bomber, highlighting its role in WWII and enduring fame, while also promoting the military game War Thunder.

title: Soldiers Who Didn't Know WW2 Was Long Over (Compilation)
summary: The video explores extraordinary cases of soldiers who continued hiding or fighting for years or decades after major wars had ended—such as Vietnamese, Japanese, and Nazi German holdouts—highlighting the persistent psychological and societal impacts of war.

title: When The U.S. Allied With North Korea

title: POV: You Wake Up In The Gulf War

summary: The video explains why certain countries—such as the United States, Switzerland, Russia, Great Britain, and Afghanistan—are considered the hardest in the world to invade, highlighting factors like geography, military strength, population, and historical resistance.

title: The most terrifying sounds and sights in war
summary: The video explores some of the most terrifying sights and psychological weapons in warfare history, including sonic weapons, napalm, biological and nuclear attacks, mass atrocities, and the enduring horror these tactics and events inflict on both combatants and civilians.

summary: The video explores several unconventional and futuristic firearms—including the Pancor Jackhammer, Dardic handgun, H&K G11, FN P90, and Arsenal Shipka—highlighting their unique designs, technical innovations, limited adoption, and enduring legacy in pop culture.

summary: This video highlights remarkable stories of elderly World War I veterans and older men—including Walter Brown, Adrien Carton de Wiart, George Patton, Nikolai Morozov, and Norman Cota—who overcame age to participate heroically in World War II.

title: 400 IQ LEGO SETS!
summary: The video showcases a variety of Lego sets and highlights the most clever and creative uses of unusual or repurposed Lego pieces, demonstrating ingenious design choices by Lego designers across multiple themes and sets.

title: LEGO Has Gone Too Far...
summary: The video counts down the ten Lego sets with the most stickers, highlighting how certain sets require builders to painstakingly apply up to 300 stickers—often tiny or repetitive—making assembly far more tedious and controversial among Lego fans.

title: Misleading LEGO Bricks...
summary: The video explains that while LEGO produces bricks in various shades that appear pink, the company officially labels these colors as purples, lavenders, or violets due to Danish language conventions, so by LEGO’s terminology, it does not make "pink" bricks.

title: Weird vs Epic LEGO Set Stickers...
summary: The video explores the history, controversy, challenges, and creative highlights of LEGO stickers, discussing infamous missteps, the difficulty of placement, fan frustrations, and how LEGO decides between printed elements and stickers for its sets.

title: LOTS OF LEGO SETS THAT BREAK THE RULES!
summary: The video highlights various rare and amusing errors found in LEGO sets' instructions, sticker placements, and box art—ranging from missing pieces and misprinted images to impossible builds—demonstrating that even LEGO occasionally makes mistakes despite their high quality standards.

title: 0 IQ LEGO SETS...
summary: This video explores some of LEGO’s most unusual or confusing set design decisions, explaining the quirky choices behind specific pieces, odd instructions, and unexpected mashups, all while showcasing LEGO’s blend of creativity, practicality, and business strategy.

title: LEGO will NEVER be the same...
summary: This video explores the evolution of LEGO minifigure heads from their detailed 1970s origins through increasingly diverse designs, skin tones, and innovative molds, reflecting both technological advances and a growing emphasis on realism and inclusivity in LEGO's history.

title: The Curse of Brittle LEGO Bricks

summary: The video explores LEGO's quirky obsessions with certain pieces—like frogs, hot dogs, bananas, carrots, and especially Batman—detailing how these elements appear in countless sets in creative and unexpected ways, reflecting both designer creativity and fan enthusiasm.

summary: The video highlights clever and creative ways LEGO designers repurpose minifigure accessories and unusual parts—like weapons, sausages, whips, and snakes—across various sets, demonstrating their ingenuity in adding hidden details and unique functions to LEGO builds.

summary: The video explores the history and creativity of LEGO’s smallest sets, highlighting classic space themes, promotional polybags, clever mini-builds, and micro-replicas, while showcasing how these tiny sets are often among LEGO’s most unique and innovative creations.

summary: This video reviews various LEGO sets, contrasting examples of excellent and poor designs across themes like Star Wars, classic space, vehicles, and architecture, while highlighting what makes certain sets innovative, detailed, and playable versus those that are uninspired or poorly executed.

summary: The video highlights a variety of mistakes and inconsistencies found in LEGO sets’ instructions, packaging, and minifigure designs, showcasing errors such as missing or extra pieces, mislabeled bags, misprinted images, and assembly step mix-ups reported by fans.

summary: The video highlights some of the weirdest, wackiest, and most creative play features ever included in LEGO sets, from minifigure-swallowing dragons and trap doors to flushing toilets, edible pellets, and even poop-shooting monsters.

summary: This video explores the history and evolution of Lego cars, highlighting key milestones, unique and imaginative vehicle sets, and Lego's role as the world's largest tire producer, while showcasing both realistic replicas and whimsical, creative designs.

summary: This video explores the most creative and unique Lego minifigure designs, highlighting distinctive elements like specialized hairpieces, accessories, transparent parts, unique molds, and Easter eggs that demonstrate Lego's ongoing innovation and attention to character detail over the years.

summary: The video showcases a wide variety of accidental errors, oddities, and rule-breaking mistakes found in LEGO sets, instructions, and packaging—from floating pieces and misprinted minifigures to mislabeled parts—demonstrating how even LEGO occasionally lets small production slip-ups reach consumers.

title: 2000 IQ LEGO BUILDING TECHNIQUES!
summary: The video highlights some of the most creative and ingenious LEGO building techniques, showcasing impressive fan-made creations—from massive dragons and kinetic dioramas to clever uses of minifigure parts and inventive architectural solutions—demonstrating the endless possibilities of LEGO artistry.

summary: The video counts down the LEGO sets with the highest number of minifigures, revealing that 1982's Fabuland Minifigure Retail Box holds the record with 80 minifigures, far surpassing modern sets like the Avengers Tower.

title: LEGO's WORST Obsessions...
summary: The video explores LEGO's recurring obsessions with certain parts and themes—such as the candle element, food items like pizza and drumsticks, and specific sets like the Millennium Falcon—highlighting how these pieces repeatedly appear in numerous sets and creative variations.

summary: This video explores the most creative and clever play features in various LEGO sets—from hidden compartments and action mechanisms to interactive parts and unique packaging—highlighting how imaginative designs enhance the fun and appeal of LEGO for fans of all ages.

summary: This video humorously explores the world of fake and knockoff Lego sets, showcasing a wide range of poorly made, bizarre, and copyright-infringing imitations—from fake Star Wars and Marvel sets to creepy Ninjago and minion figures.

title: 800 IQ LEGO SETS!
summary: The video explores the most ingenious and unconventional building techniques in LEGO sets, highlighting creative part usage—like lipstick as car exhausts and hot dog buns as lanterns—and even instances where LEGO appears to break its own rules for innovative designs.

title: THE WORST LEGO SETS
summary: The video reviews some of LEGO's worst sets ever made—highlighting design flaws, poor value, and unpopular features—culminating with the infamous unreleased giraffe set and the dismal Galidor Happy Meal toy, which received the lowest user rating.

title: LEGO is all connected...
summary: The video explores ten of the most clever hidden secrets, Easter eggs, and personal designer references found in various LEGO sets, including nods to classic themes, movies, minifigure cameos, and special connections between different LEGO lines.

summary: This video reviews several discontinued LEGO themes—including Monster Fighters, Universe, Spybotics, Inventor, Dino Attack, Avatar, Ben 10, Legends of Chima, Mixels, Atlantis, and Pharaoh's Quest—exploring their unique features, memorable sets, and reasons for their cancellation.

title: LEGO Sets You Can't Take Apart
summary: This video explores various LEGO sets and building techniques that create nearly impossible-to-disassemble "dead end" constructions, highlights notable examples, discusses removal methods, and examines the debate over design flaws and "illegal" building practices in LEGO.

title: Are These Really Just Rocks on Mars? | Perseverance Part 6
summary: The video explores how Mars has often deceived observers through optical illusions and human bias, highlighting how the Perseverance rover's discoveries—including ambiguous rock formations and actual human-made debris—remind us to critically examine what we see in the search for extraterrestrial life.

title: We've Been Receiving a Radio Signal Every 22-Minutes for 35 Years, And Astronomers Are Baffled
summary: Astronomers have discovered a mysterious, highly stable 22-minute radio signal—likely from an unknown type of cosmic object—challenging existing theories about neutron stars and pulsars, and hinting at new astrophysical phenomena beyond current understanding.

title: What Will the Solar Maximum do to Earth in 2025?
summary: This video explains how the Sun's 11-year cycles significantly influence life on Earth by affecting technology, climate, ecosystems, and possibly even human health and behavior, with the next solar maximum expected in 2025.

title: Light Can Go Backwards Through Time, And This Experiment Proves It
summary: The video explores recent experiments showing that light can behave in ways that defy classical physics—including traveling faster or slower than its usual speed and even appearing to interfere with itself across time—raising new questions about the true nature of light and causality.

title: The Uncomfortable Truth: Why We Are Heading Towards Complete Isolation
summary: The video explains how the universe's accelerating expansion led scientists to theorize dark energy—an invisible force making up about 68% of the universe—and explores ongoing research, including the Euclid telescope, aimed at uncovering its mysterious nature.

title: What Satellites Can See From Space Is Troubling
summary: The video explores the rapid growth and increasing resolution of Earth-observing satellites, highlighting their powerful benefits for science and society but raising significant concerns about privacy as surveillance capabilities become ever more advanced and ubiquitous.

title: For the Last 33 Years, Hubble Has Been Seeing Something It Wasn't Designed For | Hubble Supercut
summary: This video explores the remarkable contributions of the Hubble Space Telescope to our understanding of the solar system, highlighting its unexpected discoveries, planetary observations, and complementary relationship with the James Webb Space Telescope.

title: How NANOGrav Uses Dead Stars to Detect Spacetime Ripples
summary: The video explains how the NANOGrav collaboration detected strong evidence for a gravitational wave background—subtle ripples in spacetime likely caused by supermassive black hole binaries and possibly the Big Bang—using an array of precisely monitored pulsars spread across the galaxy.

title: Something is Still Lurking Below the Moon's Surface | India's Chandrayaan 3 Moon Mission ISRO
summary: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission made history by achieving the first landing at the Moon's south pole, yielding important data on lunar elements—though it failed to directly detect surface water ice, suggesting future searches must probe beneath the regolith.

title: The Storm So Big It Can Take Out Satellites
summary: The video explains how massive, planet-wide dust storms form on Mars approximately every 5.5 Earth years, the mechanisms behind their development, their impacts on robots and potential human settlers, and the challenges these storms pose for future exploration and habitation.

title: What the Upcoming Geomagnetic Reversal Will Do to Earth
summary: The video explores Earth's geomagnetic reversals, explaining their causes, historical frequency, potential dangers—including increased radiation and technological disruptions—and concludes that while the risks are real, such events are slow, giving humanity time to adapt.

title: The Best Earth-like Exoplanet Has 4 Major Problems
summary: The video explains that while thousands of exoplanets have been discovered, none found so far are truly suitable for human habitation due to factors like harsh stellar environments, tidal locking, and gravity, making the search for a real "Earth 2.0" ongoing.

title: The Deepest We Have Ever Seen Into the Sun | SDO 4K
summary: This video explores the Sun’s dynamic atmosphere and surface using different wavelengths of electromagnetic light, revealing features like solar flares, coronal holes, prominences, sunspots, and granules, and highlighting how advanced imaging uncovers the Sun’s hidden complexity.

title: We May Have the Key To the Theory of Everything... Let me Explain With a Model | Part 1
summary: The video explores the quest for a grand unifying theory in physics—highlighting the challenges in merging quantum mechanics and relativity, introducing string theory and extra dimensions, and presenting the host’s own conceptual approach to explaining the universe’s underlying structure.

title: The Final Cassini Images that Stunned the World | NASA Cassini Supercut
summary: This video explores the Cassini-Huygens mission’s legacy, detailing its groundbreaking discoveries about Saturn’s rings, moons, atmosphere, and unresolved mysteries—including Saturn’s day length and magnetic field—made possible by spectacular data gathered during Cassini's dramatic Grand Finale.

title: James Webb Discovered Something So Improbable, It Shouldn’t Ever Happen
summary: The James Webb Space Telescope has discovered 40 pairs of Jupiter-mass planets, called JuMBOs, orbiting each other in the Orion Nebula, challenging existing theories of star and planet formation due to their surprising frequency and improbable nature.

title: What the Moon Will Do to Earth Next Decade
summary: The video explains how the Moon’s 18.6-year lunar nodal cycle intensifies tides, and combined with rising sea levels from climate change, is expected to cause dramatic, widespread coastal flooding and ecological impacts in the mid-2030s, urging urgent adaptation measures.

title: The Facts Nearly Everyone Gets Wrong About Pluto
summary: This video answers four key questions about Pluto, explaining why it’s hard to image from Earth, why Pluto and Charon orbit a shared point in space, how New Horizons captured bright images despite Pluto’s distance from the Sun, and why Pluto is classified as a dwarf planet.

title: The 9 Experiments That Will Change Your View of Light (And Blow Your Mind)
summary: This video explains how various quantum physics experiments—especially those involving light—challenge our understanding of reality, demonstrating that light and matter behave unpredictably, are altered by observation, and may even allow information to travel backward in time.

title: How Destroying Mercury Would Help Humanity
summary: The video explores the concept of Dyson spheres as a potential long-term solution to Earth's impending energy crisis, analyzing their feasibility, required resources, and the mathematics behind harnessing the Sun's full energy output for future civilization.

title: The Suspicious Similarities Between Earth and Mars
summary: The video explains how scientists search for alien life by studying ancient extremophilic microbes on Earth, whose unique adaptations and biosignatures guide the hunt for life on planets like Mars and Europa, and discusses future telescopes advancing this quest.

title: The Inexplicable Cosmic Coincidence That Suggests the Universe Was Designed | Part 1
summary: This video explores why the measured amount of dark energy in the universe is far lower than theoretical predictions—allowing galaxies, stars, and life to exist—and discusses whether this remarkable "fine-tuning" is a coincidence or evidence of deeper underlying principles.

title: Journey Across the Solar System Through the Eyes of the Voyager Probes
summary: The video traces the extraordinary 47-year journey of NASA’s Voyager 1 and 2 probes, highlighting their groundbreaking discoveries about the outer planets and their moons, and reflecting on their lasting legacy as humanity’s farthest-traveled space explorers.

title: This Makes Me Sad: The Crash on the Moon that Could've Easily Been Avoided
summary: This video examines the failure of Russia's Luna-25 Moon mission, attributing its crash to technological setbacks, rushed competition with India, and Western sanctions, while underscoring the importance of international collaboration in successful space exploration.

title: What's Happening With Antimatter at CERN? Scientists Are Stumped Again
summary: This video explains the nature of antimatter, the differences and similarities between matter and antimatter—especially regarding gravity—and details a recent CERN experiment showing that antimatter, like matter, falls downward due to gravity, challenging alternative theories.

title: Kilonova Size Explosions Are Popping Off in Empty Space
summary: This video explores the mystery of Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transients (LFBOTs)—extraordinarily bright, short-lived cosmic explosions that have baffled astronomers since 2018, challenging existing theories and highlighting the need for more data to understand their origins.

title: What Will Humanity Do If We Ever Discover Aliens?
summary: This video explores the scientific search for alien life, discussing definitions of life, likely conditions and forms for extraterrestrial organisms, the ongoing hunt within our solar system and beyond, possible evidence for aliens, and the challenges and implications of first contact.

title: The Star that Looks Like a Black Hole
summary: The video explores the nature and lifecycle of stars, delving into hypothetical exotic stars like gravastars made of vacuum energy, and discusses the ongoing scientific debate over whether some black holes could actually be these exotic objects linked to dark energy.

title: The Bizarre Shaped Objects that Block the Sun on Other Planets
summary: The video explains solar eclipses on Earth and other planets, showcases NASA's stunning images and videos of eclipses across the solar system, discusses their scientific importance, and highlights the April 2024 North American solar eclipse.

title: The Images That Will Change Your View of Our Moon Forever (And Blow Your Mind) | LRO 4K
summary: This video explores the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter's detailed mapping and imaging of the Moon since 2009, highlighting its discoveries of craters, mountains, volcanic features, surface changes, and their significance for lunar science and future human exploration.

title: Aftermath of the Asteroid Impact that Killed the Dinosaurs
summary: This video explores the theories behind the mass extinction event that wiped out the dinosaurs 66 million years ago—focusing on asteroid impact, volcanic activity, or both—and examines how life on Earth dramatically changed and eventually recovered.

title: This Object Could Rewrite Everything We Know About Black Holes
summary: This video explains the theoretical existence of white holes and wormholes—spacetime phenomena predicted by general relativity as counterparts and extensions of black holes—and discusses their possible connection to black hole death, parallel universes, and the origins of our universe.

title: This Model Explains WHY Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle Happens | Theory of Everything Part 2
summary: The video explores how string theory could explain quantum phenomena—such as quantization, uncertainty, and wave-particle duality—by modeling particles as convergences of waves on fundamental strings, and hints at extending this to cover relativity in future episodes.

title: I want to change things.
summary: The creator of Astrum shares the channel’s growth journey, discusses the challenges of relying on YouTube's algorithm for educational space content, and invites viewers to support future projects and stability by joining their Patreon membership.

title: How Scientifically Accurate Is Dune?
summary: This video from Astrum analyzes the scientific plausibility of key concepts from the Dune universe—such as planetary environments, interstellar travel, force fields, and sandworms—ultimately concluding that while imaginative, most are highly fictional or currently impossible.

title: What's NASA Trying to Find at the Bottom of the Ocean?
summary: The video explores NASA's use of Earth's deep oceans—due to their similarities with conditions on distant icy moons like Europa—as a testing ground for developing technologies and strategies to search for extraterrestrial life in our solar system.

title: Aftermath of the 2024 Noto Japan Earthquake (And Why It Took Scientists Completely By Surprise)
summary: The video explains the unusual geological factors behind the deadly January 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake in Japan, its surprising impacts, and how ongoing scientific research and advanced engineering help mitigate earthquake risks in such vulnerable regions.

title: The Closest Planet Outside Our Solar System Is Within Reach | Proxima Centauri
summary: This video explores Proxima Centauri, our closest stellar neighbor, detailing its properties, discovery, the recent detection of potentially habitable exoplanets, ongoing scientific debates, and ambitious future plans to send probes for direct exploration.

title: Quasar Spotted in the Milky Way!
summary: The video explains how microquasars—smaller, less powerful versions of quasars—exist within our Milky Way, and how studying objects like SS 433 helps scientists better understand the extreme physics of quasars throughout the universe.

title: What Did ESA See Around Mercury? | BepiColombo
summary: The video explores the challenges and scientific goals of the BepiColombo mission to Mercury, detailing its journey, recent findings from flybys, and its plan to enhance our understanding of Mercury’s geology, magnetic field, and exosphere upon arrival in 2025.

title: A Shift in the Earth's Cycles Is Coming - Will It Affect You?
summary: This video explains the major natural cycles shaping Earth's climate—such as Milankovitch cycles, El Niño/La Niña, jet streams, geomagnetic reversals, solar and lunar influences—and concludes that while these cycles are significant, recent rapid global warming is primarily due to human activity.

title: This Substance Is the Most Dangerous Threat to Earth
summary: This video from Astrum explores how melting polar ice, driven by human-induced climate change, is disrupting Earth's climate systems, potentially causing significant sea level rise, ecological threats, and extreme weather by 2100, while emphasizing the need for human adaptation and action.

title: These Images Explain Why Venera Went Silent on Venus | 4K
summary: This video explores the history and findings of robotic missions to Venus, revealing its extreme atmospheric and surface conditions, mysterious chemical composition, surface mapping via radar, and the ongoing search for potential signs of microbial life.

title: What They Didn't Teach You in School About Jupiter | Our Solar System's Planets
summary: This video provides a comprehensive overview of Jupiter, exploring its immense mass, storms, gravitational influence on the solar system, unique atmospheric features, magnetosphere, rings, and moons, highlighting its vital protective role and ongoing scientific exploration.

title: Betelgeuse looks a lot stranger than we thought, and physics shouldn't allow it
summary: The video explores whether the giant star Betelgeuse is truly rotating at an unusually high speed or if turbulent surface activity is creating an optical illusion, highlighting new research and the need for higher-resolution observations to resolve the mystery.

title: Why It's Harder to Crash Into The Sun Than to Leave The Solar System
summary: This video explains why sending Earth's toxic waste, especially nuclear waste, into the Sun is extremely difficult, risky, and expensive due to orbital mechanics, fuel requirements, and the high potential for catastrophic launch failures, making safer earthbound disposal methods more practical.

title: What They Didn't Teach You in School About Mars | Our Solar System's Planets 4K
summary: This video explores the fascinating features of Mars—its similarities and differences with Earth, stunning 4K imagery, active geology, unique atmosphere, moons, and dust storms—highlighting why it captivates scientists and may be humanity's next destination.

title: What They Didn't Teach You in School About Earth | Our Solar System's Planets
summary: This video from Astrum explores what makes Earth unique in the universe, covering its structure, atmosphere, timekeeping, seasons, magnetic field, plate tectonics, water cycle, and the vital role of the Moon in supporting life.

title: Physics Gets Weird at the End of the Universe
summary: The video explores the four main scientific theories for how the universe might end—Heat Death (Big Freeze), Big Crunch, Big Rip, and Big Bounce—explaining how each depends on the nature of dark energy and our universe’s evolving physics.

title: Mars Is Doing Something Weird at Night
summary: This video argues that while Mars’ surface is being explored for evidence of past life, the most likely place for living organisms today is deep beneath the Martian surface, in protected underground environments similar to Earth’s deep biosphere.

title: You guys are awesome, thanks for the 2 million subs
summary: The creator of Astrum celebrates reaching 2 million subscribers by reflecting on the channel’s 11-year journey, highlighting its most impactful videos about space and science, and expressing deep gratitude to viewers and supporters.

title: The Star Explosion So Powerful, It Compressed Our Atmosphere from 2 Billion Light Years Away
summary: The video explores the unprecedented "BOAT" gamma-ray burst of 2022—the brightest ever observed—and examines how its unusual properties challenge our understanding of gamma-ray bursts, heavy element formation, and possibly even the Standard Model of physics.

title: What Voyager Detected at the Edge of the Solar System
summary: This video chronicles the Voyager 1 and 2 missions, detailing their groundbreaking exploration of the outer planets, discoveries about moons and planetary rings, historic entry into interstellar space, and their enduring legacy as humanity’s farthest-traveled spacecraft.

title: What They Didn't Teach You in School about Neptune | Our Solar System's Planets
summary: This video explores the fascinating planet Neptune, covering its discovery, unique dynamic atmosphere, extreme weather, internal structure, rings, and moons—especially Triton—highlighting what makes Neptune distinct among the outer planets of our solar system.

title: How Are Ghost Particles Affecting Earth? | IceCube Observatory Discovery
summary: This video explores the IceCube Neutrino Observatory in Antarctica, explaining how it detects elusive neutrinos using sensors embedded deep in ice, and how this helps scientists study extreme cosmic events and expand our understanding of the universe.

title: NASA Tried to Screw Astronauts Over Money - and Paid the Price Big Time
summary: The Apollo 15 postal scandal saw astronauts secretly carry unauthorized postal covers to the Moon for profit, leading to a major controversy, congressional hearings, damaged reputations, and lasting restrictions on what personal items astronauts may take into space.
